description:
My friend and I were in the Mission Bay Area and decided to grab dinner. We yelped what was in the area and Saap Ver came up and we decided to give it a try. 

After sitting down, we took a look at the menu, and we were lightweight overwhelmed. There's so many options and we literally didn't know what to order. After browsing for what felt like forever, we decided on the Thai Sausage with Crispy Rice Salad (mild) and the Pork Spare Rib Soup (mild) and a side of sticky rice - I really enjoy rice and soup together and this was a nice combo! 

We enjoyed both of these dishes! Both of these dishes were extremely flavorful and the presentation for both dishes were nice. I did find both of these dishes pretty spicy for a mild though, but I didn't mind. I definitely enjoyed the salad more between the two of these dishes! There were many textures in the dishes and the flavors of everything went really well together! Highly recommend!

Overall I really enjoyed this place! I would come. I'd definitely come back and try their other dishes!
author: Stacey Y.

description:
Walking past Saap Ver and you see people happy and chatting away with friends. The ambiance is dark and there is a bar, and it is pretty spacious. Busy on a Wednesday evening. It was even busy on a Monday night. 

The hostess greeted me upon walking in. I requested for a menu for food to-go. The waitress said it would take 30 minutes for them to make the food. 

This authentic Thai restaurant is NOT vegetarian/vegan friendly. I specifically ordered pad see ew, vegetarian with tofu. It arrived with no tofu. When I asked about it she said it costs extra. That makes no sense as beef costs more than tofu. I would have ordered both tofu and veggies.  She gave off a bad energy so I would rather leave with just veggies than wait another entire 30 minutes to fix the order. 

Also they are not friendly towards artists.  Both the hostess and waitress gave me dirty looks because my eye makeup was too out-of-the-ordinary for their liking. 

The portions are small. Last time I was here one year ago, I ordered food for both me and my brother (he was not physically present) and they skimped. It was not enough food for two people. I had even ordered two dishes at the time. It was even smaller portions this time. One dish 15 dollars vegetarian with no tofu. The worst part of the experience at Sap veer was the poor customer service, awful attitude, judgmental stares.

This place is awful and reeks of bad vibes. Highly not recommended.
author: Lydia V.

description:
I came here on a Monday night around 8:30pm and it was pretty busy but we got seated right away. The decor is really unique and a fun environment to get a bite to eat. A really nice space for both big and small groups. 

Me and my friend ordered the Tom Saap Pork Spare Rib Soup, the Thai Sausage with Crispy Rice Salad, and a side of Sticky Rice. I enjoyed the flavors in all the dishes. The spareribs were tender and the soup was hot and sour. Even though the salad was a little hard to eat, the crispy rice added good texture and was very flavorful. The servers were also friendly and very attentive. 

Even though we didn't order any drinks, they do have a full bar and a bunch of cocktails and drinks. I would definitely come back to try other items from their menu.
author: Michael L.

description:
Food was solid here, and they have a giant projector that my boyfriend loved so we can eat and watch football. 

We got the shrimp Pad Thai, Clay Pot Sea Bass, and Tom Koga soup. Everything was very good. The sea bass looked strange and unappealing, but the flavor was light and great! 

Would come back if I was in the area and craved Thai, but wouldn't go out of my way with all the great places in SF.
author: Miranda N.

description:
A couple good friends of mine brought me here for dinner one night when I was in town for work. This is one of their favorite Thai spots in the city. 

The vibe and decor at this place was pretty fun. They must have been pretty short staffed the night I came because when I walked in, I had to wait several minutes for someone to come greet and seat me. 

My friends recommended this cocktail they'd had there before that had some kind of lemongrass infused liquor and chili vodka or something, but they said they'd be discontinuing that drink so we were pretty bummed. 

We started with the fresh rolls to start which were fresh and tasty. 

For my main I had the pumpkin and tofu curry with garlic ginger rice. The curry was thick and decadent, but could've had a bit more pumpkin in it. 

One friend ordered the sautéed beef with string beans which was super tasty and well seasoned. I would get that again. 

My other friend had the spicy sizzling seafood which was ok but kind of underwhelming. She loved it but I thought the ingredients were not super well incorporated. 

Their dishes also came out about 10 minutes after mine so timing could've been a bit better. Prices were average for what you can normally find in SF. Overall a fine experience.
author: Ashtar B.

description: Ordered pad see ew beef to go for lunch. The flavor is good, medium spice level is actually pretty spicy - go easy if you are not crazy for spicy food. Only complaint really is the portion size - for $14 you would have expected more noodles and beef in it.
author: Jessie L.

description: This place was recommended by one of clients and what a great restaurant. We ordered the papaya salad , pork belly and Thai sausage-crispy rice salad . They were prepared in the most delicious way and very close to the authentic food in Bangkok. This is hands down one of the best places to get a good Thai dinner at a very affordable price ! From now on , we will come here every time we are in the city.
author: Pedro C.

description:
Came by for lunch the last couple of days and it was a decent experience both times! Staff was friendly and water was nice and cold upon arrival.

Thai tea is decent, better than most, and not too sweet. Thai tea is also pretty strong.

Ordered the Pad See Ew Beef the other day with spicy and it was delicious and fresh. The beef was rough and overcooked while the noodles were very fresh and the soy sauce was perfect! Portions were so large that I couldn't finish!

Ordered the Pad Thai omelette the following day and it was decent. The omelette, was delicious whereas the noodles were all stuck together...something was wrong. The 4 shrimps were decent sized. Again, the portions were too large...

Their chicken satay appetizer was smokey, flavorful, and tender. Quite impressive!

The samosas were decent too. 

The fresh rolls were a miss.
author: Derek S.

description:
I have come here a bunch of times and it can be a little hit or miss. Most of the dishes are amazing. Be careful with some like the crispy rice salad--a medium spicy dish was screaming with heat. I tried to eat it (I am fan of spicy--my native cuisine is spicy) but after 3 bites, my eyes were watering, my head was pounding, and I was choking. This is actually the second time this has happened. 
I was also stunned on my last bill to see that they automatically rang up a 20% tip for my meal when there was only 2 of us dining. I didn't make a stink about it but I will next time.
author: Monica B.

description:
Dine in and takeout equally delicious. I really love the vibe here and all the employees are friendly and attentive. Haven't had a bad experience yet and I've come over 10 times now. Tonight I saw their gin and watermelon fruit bowl and had to order it. So good! See photo. We ate all the watermelon and scrapped the rest out 

My go to dishes are chicken wings, pork shoulder salad, Tom yum noodle soup, pad sew ew and yellow curry chicken. Their menu is quite extensive and we haven't explored yet.

There usually have their projector on. Watched a few Giants and Warriors games here.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
This is a cute little spot with great food.

I would say the larb here in my opinion isn't the best. Everything bout it was great minus the texture of the meat.

The duck dishes here are really good.

There wasn't really anything I didn't like. 

We ordered a curry, soup, chicken, and pork ribs amongst other things.

-

Service was great.
author: Lilian L.

description:
Cool casual vibe, great cocktails and an interesting selection of dishes.  So excited when I first saw the menu -- was hoping this could be the Lotus of Siam of SF.  While that wasn't the case, there's still lots to love.

* Pin Up Girl:  Gin, watermelon and lime juice served in a whole mini watermelon.  The watermelon was sweet and this was delicious!  Worth the $18.  5/5
* Cut Cut Cut :  The other fruit cup cocktail, this one was made with vodka, hibiscus syrup, pineapple and lime juice served in a whole pineapple.  Sadly the pineapple was a bit underripe and the cocktail leaked out onto the plate, but it was still quite good.  4/5
* Thai sausage with crispy rice salad:  Spicy, salty, sour, tangy:  not quite the LOS version but still very satisfying.  4.5/5
* Crispy pork green bean:  I can see why this is a polarizing dish -- the pork is somewhat crispy somewhat chewy.  I liked it but wonder if it could be a bit more tender instead of chewy.  Sadly not spicy.  3.5/5
* Deep fried whole tilapia with chili sauce:  this looked great but the chili sauce made the fish a bit too soggy, plus it wasn't spicy at all!  Tons of fried basil were a nice touch but it could have been better. 3.5/5

Overall we loved the vibe and the drinks.  We're disappointed that only the rice salad was spicy, but there were enough intriguing dishes to make it worth a repeat visit.
author: Alice C.

description:
On our way to the San Francisco Ice Cream Festival, a friend and I stopped by Saap Ver for some food to tide us over before stuffing ourselves with dairy treats. I'm very glad we did -- I liked it more than the ice cream!

The first thing that struck me was the decor. The walls are plastered in retro Thai movie posters, and there's a cute sports bar off to the side. I've never been to Thailand, but I imagine it's something a lot like Saap Ver.

The second thing was the menu. It's just plain vast. Rice dishes, curries, specials, noodles, meat, and more specials line the pages. It took some real focus and determination, but I eventually settled on the spicy red chili beef, while my less-hungry friend grabbed some of the meatballs.

The balls came out first. The sauce was sweet, with a hint of spicy of tanginess, but the meat itself was underwhelming. Moist, but otherwise unremarkable.

My beef, though, was lovely. The sauce was a top-notch combo of umami and spicy, and the peppercorns were like little popping boba of flavor. The meat was a liiiiittle tough, though; it would have benefited from a little tenderizing before cooking.

Overall, Saap Ver's got some good flavors going on, but could do with upping their meat quality game a bit. I'd go back to sample something else from the expansive menu, but it's far :(
author: Shawn W.

description: Ate lunch since another nearby restaurant had long wait. Beef noodle soup was good, maybe need better beef broth. Egg crepe was very good. I thoughtthat this entree was tastiest. Pork Rat Nah had too much oyster flavored gravy. Mai Chapt. Very good decor and not too crowded on weekday at 1230pm. Big screen TV for sports viewing. Three unisex toilets very clean.
author: Clifford W.

description:
Most authentic Thai I've had in the Bay Area. They don't appeal to the typical American tastes with the excess sweetness or tamarind. Perfectly salty with fish sauce and hits hard on the Thai pepper spice! Just the way I love it. Seriously the best Tom yum in town. I normally get it with tofu which they will add extra veggies in and makes it that much more yummy. Medium spicy is pretty spicy here and I am no stranger to spicy food, I love it. 

All the appetizers I've tried are good. We normally opt for fish cakes or spring/fresh rolls. They also have shrimp egg rolls which are always good if you want to indulge in fried food. Papaya salad is the perfect mix of sour, spicy, salty. 

For entree I always get the same thing: pumpkin tofu curry! Ooh so yummy. Hits the spot when you're craving something hearty. I normally order plain white rice but recently discovered they offer sticky rice and ginger garlic rice...say whaaaa!!! I can usually always go for Thai food and I have to say I'm lucky that this one is close to my house and the best in town.
author: Stine H.

description:
On the hunt for yet another order of steamed chicken, I traipsed along 8th Street from Market all the way down to the Design District to find this rather lively large space on Division Street. The moment I entered at around 7PM on a Thursday evening, the bustling space evoked the spirited atmosphere of a Singaporean hawker center with a touch of San Francisco kitsch in the vintage movie magazine covers being used as wallpaper and Christmas drop lights hanging from the ceiling (photo: http://bit.ly/2pcEn2f). The dining profile was young, mostly Asian, and likely working at start-ups nearby judging from the Ben Sherman vibe of their clothing.

I was seated straight away on a lonely banquette table and perused their rather lengthy menu to see what I could get away with for dinner. I also learned the literal translation of Saap Ver was 'Damn Delicious'. OK, fair enough. I started with the $8 Fresh Rolls, purely vegetarian with an extra thin rice paper wrapper and an extra thick peanut sauce. They were stuffed with lettuce, cabbage, cucumber, carrot, vermicelli noodles, and tofu (photo: http://bit.ly/2FQHoPV). Damn, it was delicious though not entirely unique in execution. My main event was the $12 Chicken Ginger Rice, their take on Hainan chicken which I dared to ask if I could have paleo.

The server asked the chef who refused as he felt the rice was the point of ordering the dish. It was indeed as the plump chicken thigh was resting on top of a large mound of ginger-infused rice with cucumber slices and soy sauce on the side (photo: http://bit.ly/2pioeZd). The poultry was tender and just what I wanted as it was boneless but not skinless. I added a $5 side of Steamed Broccoli in order to make it more paleo, and it worked for the most part since the veg was fresh (photo: http://bit.ly/2HC86t4). But hell, it didn't stop me from devouring the ginger rice much to my nutritional chagrin. Damn, it was delicious and probably worthy of a return visit with Jamie W.

FOOD - 4 stars...saap ver!
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...the Southeast Asian party vibe worked for me...surprisingly
SERVICE - 4 stars...pretty attentive to this solo diner
TOTAL - 4 stars...nice to find a Hainan chicken worth getting at a real hawker center
author: Ed U.

description:
Tasty Thai food, friendly stuff and great atmosphere. If you're not super familiar with Thai cuisine, choose something from a daily menu board or ask for help. 

The line is not super long most of the time. The place is rather big, it is good for couples and groups. But it's noisy in the evenings. Average waiting time is around 20-30mins, which is lightning fast for SF.  

There are not that many vegan options, but as a vegan you still have some decent choices of veggies or tofu. Cocktails are amazing! And the bar... with huge TV.
author: Liza B.

description:
I really wanted to like this place. The decor is super cute and there were a ton of people eating dinner late on a Thursday.

We ordered Pad Kee and Spicy Red Chili Beef. Although the beef had "spicy" in the title, the pad kee was so spicy that it was pretty unpleasant to eat. I am a fan of spicy food and I still didn't really enjoy it. The beef was just ok. The meat was not great quality and the veggies were under-cooked.

I ended up ordering a Thai iced tea for my dining companion who was pretty traumatized by the pad kee spiciness. The tea was really tasty.

Service was inattentive but not the worst. I wish I had loved the food as much as some other reviewers. Maybe they were just having a bad night, but I probably won't be back.
author: Rachel G.

description: Amazing place for Thai food, and it even has a bar! The pork belly and curries were amazing, and when you request it spicy, it's actually spicy. Be aware that this place does get crowded on the evenings and over the weekend.
author: Andrew Y.

description: This place has been in business for 2 years now. I love the setting but the food I was not too impressed, just OK for a quick bite at lunch time.
author: Mehran A.

description: "We just had a bonanza in flavortown." The words I spoke moments after finishing our delicious meal. Look I'm no Thai food expert but I know delicious when it touches my mouth and this is it. We ordered the pad see ew with beef, the dinner plate with papaya salad and beef jerky, and the fried tilapia....oh and coconut ice cream. They mean spice if you ask for it and thank goodness I ordered a Thai iced tea to wash it all down because we weren't shy about chili's. Everything was flavorful, smelled like the smells that you expect, real Thai people giving food advice, and the couple next to us ordered the watermelon drink and that looked like fun also haha. We'll definitely be back for more since we live nearby. Bring these people business but don't get overly crowded ok? Lol it's worth a shout
author: Guisela L.

description:
Very delicious and I like that the name means "damn good" in Thai!

Sat down here for lunch with the clients yesterday and this was their pick. Ordered quickly and they have a great atmosphere with awesome movie posters from old films all over the wall. The menu is pretty standard as far as Thai dishes go but the delivery and presentation of the food is quite nice.

Dishes ordered:

Pad see ew: 4/5 - little bit greasier than I usually like but very flavorful and VERY mild. I bet they saw me as a pasty white guy and thought I couldn't take the heat

Red curry with brown rice: 5/5 this dish had great presentation and the curry was rich and flavorful

Chicken ginger fried rice: 5/5 once again great presentation, good quality ingredients and a little on the pricier side for a fried rice dish at $16 but still good!

What you can expect from lunches in San Francisco.

Would definitely return and try some other dishes another time.
author: Gabriel C.

description: We came here for beer (they have a full bar bless their souls) and were impressed with the authenticity of the food selection. They have way  more then pad Thai and pad see ew... There were different larbs, squid salad, crispy salad, papaya salad, tilapia dishes. It all looked sooo good. They even have durian black rice dessert which I thought was tasty (probably not for everyone), and surprisingly did not had a strong scent. We also had a sour soup and fried wings which went well with beer. Wished we had room to order more but would definitely come back.
author: Kimmie H.

description: Love the atmosphere in the restaurant! The foods taste authentic! You gotta spare your stomach because the foods come in large portion. However it takes quite long for them to serve. If you walk in there with an empty stomach, you should make a quick decision on your food in order to get the food faster.
author: Nui W.

description:
Booked a table on Yelp and found no records of reservation there when we arrived. The host was a bit rude to the point that we had to prove our email confirmation in order to get a table even when the house was half empty... not a good start!
We did not feel welcomed there, so hard to get our waitress' attention. Food was mediocre for the price they ask for ($28 for a fish clay pot with taste and portion worse than $10 Chinatown one?!?). One star is for their watermelon gin-tonic that served in a whole melon.
author: Craig W.

description: I really wanted to like this place. It is super cute and close by. I got the red beef curry and it was crazy spicy and just didn't taste that good. We also got the the house fried rice and they actually tasted pretty good but they told us it wasn't pricy and it was. I don't think I will go back.
author: Tina L.

description:
Had a nice dinner with friends here. We got the beef noodle soup, pork rad na moo, red curry beef, yellow curry chicken, and fresh rolls. The food was tasty enough and consistent with American Thai flavors. 

Their spice levels are on the high side, my friends said, but I thought my "medium" spicy dish was fairly mild.

Service was solid, as was the ambiance. The giant Thai movie posters on the walls were interesting, and it was loud, but not deafening, inside.
author: Novelty B.

description:
I've been waiting my entire San Francisco life to say this. I finally found my favorite Thai restaurant in the city! 4.5 stars, so legit!

omg.

So, we were walking around the Design District and bumped into this place. No wait, Thai food, a welcoming smell of faint fish sauce as you open the door, and recognition on the wall had me interested in less than ten seconds.

Having been to Thailand (which btw, the food there is absolutely unreeeaaaal!), I often have thai chili and fresh coconut dreams. I can now come to Saap Ver to get my fix. If I had to give the street food in Bangkok a 10, Saap Ver is a very high 7. I love this place!

The menu is pretty large, I wanted everything. But, between the two of us we started off with jasmine tea, stir fried squid in salty egg yolk, red chili beef, chicken pad thai, and white rice on the side. I also wanted red curry and tom kha soup, but that would a little gluttonous. So, we stuck with three entrees.

The red chili beef was spicy rich in flavor, so delicious! The squid was super fresh, and you could taste the tamarind in the pad thai (no ketchup used here!).

Just like in Thailand, the food here is really addicting, you really can't stop eating it (nor do you want to). It's so flavorful AND get this: they have "thai spicy"! You will never have to ask for hot sauce if you opt for thai spicy. But, be ready for your mouth to burn baby buuurn!

The service is really attentive, the waiter was super chatty and nice. The ambiance is great too, very much reminded me of the nightlife in Bangkok.


I can't wait to come back and try other food. It's "Damn Good!" =P
author: Shereen A.

description:
If you want food that differs 90% of the Thai restaurant.
This is the place.

Roasted Pork with Crispy Pork Belly
   over rice
   Chinese sausage
   boiled egg

Grilled Salted Whole Tilapia 
    Lemongrass
    Grilled Eggplant
    Thai Spices
author: S.K. Y.

description:
Had a late lunch at Saap Ver Thai restaurant on Sunday with daughter K in S.F. Saap. Ver is actually big for a Thai place. There is a long bar and lots of tables and booths through out. Everything including the menu is decorated in Thai movie decor. There is even a theater movie project as an ornament as you walk in the front door. It was a nice day in S.F. however they left the front door open to save on the air con cost. ***bad***. We were waving flies away from our food during lunch. They were pretty busy for 2:30 pm on a Sunday. The menu is extensive and we ordered the following dishes.

Squid Salad good portions we asked for medium spicy but its really spicy

Pad Thai noodles we ordered this after our initial order to combat the spiciness of the squid salad. 

Grilled whole Tilapia came with several dipping sauces. The Tilapia was quite large. 

Deep fried chicken wings were salty and tasty

Pork belly dish was flavored well but the pork belly was cut into tiny pieces and would have been better had the pork been larger. 

Service was good. S.F. prices $89 before tip. Street parking only and could be a problem with the popular Dumpling Time restaurant right across the street.
author: George F.

description:
This is my new favorite Thai restaurant. Previous favorites were Farmhouse Kitchen (which has gotten way too weird, plus their red curry sauce is one-note and used in almost everything) and Kin Khao (which is far away from me, hard to park near, and hard to get a table at), and Lers Ros (I guess I just got bored of it).

Most Thai restaurants in America have just the standard "American Thai" menu... you got your 4 different curries with 3 different meat options, your Pad Thai / See Yoo / Kee Mau noodle dishes, and the standard stir fries like beef with green beans... you know.

I'm not Thai, and I'm no expert on Thai cuisine, but while Saap Ver does have the standards, it also has a lot of dishes that I haven't seen before, and when I eat them, they're all very yummy, and a little different -- and more like when I visited Thailand a few years ago. I especially like the street food inspired dishes, which are stylistically different than most of the Thai food you typically see.

My favorite dish is the Crispy Pork Belly Green Bean, which is heavily seasoned with lots of chili paste, ginger, young peppercorns, thai basil, etc. It's very rich, nicely spicy, and the serving size is generous.

I also really enjoy the look inside this place. It's quite trendy and modern, but in a very Thai way. It reminds me of some of the hip new places we ate at in Koh Samui -- which sure, were touristy, but also really fun.
author: Jon E.

description:
Not sure if I just came on a bad day or if it's always like this): I really wanted to love this place, but the experience was a bit subpar. 

Came for a late Saturday lunch and it was pretty empty inside the large restaurant. The space has so great decorations! Fun Thai pop culture art and posters up on the walls. They gave a very nice looking bar and a big TV screen playing whatever big game there was on.

My friend and I ordered the chicken satay appetizer, yellow curry, and pad Thai. 

Chicken satay was yum!!! Can't really mess this dish up, but it was a great way to start the meal. It came out probably 5 minutes after ordering.

8 minutes after that my curry came out. I thought my friends pad Thai would be out at the same time or soon after, but it didn't come out for soooooo long!!! We had to ask where it was b/c if had literally been another 15 minutes!! I felt bad eating my curry when she didn't have a meal, but it was getting cold and she insisted. Finally here came out and it was missing a lot of things a traditional pad Thai would come with?? No peanuts or green onion?? Interesting...

Anyways, the noodles weren't that amazing. Definitely have had a more satisfying pad Thai. My curry was solid. Both dishes can't with sooooo much chicken which was awesome. 

I thought it was a pretty cool spot by looks but I'm pretty whatever about the food. Maybe I'll come by and give this place another try.
author: Courtney N.

description:
Most people probably come here for food, but my friends and I came for drinks while we were waiting to get seated at Dumpling Time across the street.

First thing you notice is the decor. Colorful flags hang across the ceiling and the walls are decked out with movie posters of past Thai movies. You feel like you're walking into a festival! Very possibly the most colorful and unique Thai restaurant I've ever been to in terms of the environment.

I was impressed by their drinks and cocktail menu, which is more extensive than the typical Thai restaurant. They have happy hour Monday to Friday 4:30 to 6 pm and offer a selection of happy hour drinks and small bites. Unfortunately since we just missed their happy hour.

I really wanted to get the Tang Mo Lover which comes served in a small watermelon, but it seemed like a lot of alcohol to drink on an empty stomach, so I opted for something smaller. I forgot exactly what I ordered but it was pretty good. They also have a small wine and beer selection and one friend ended up ordering a sangria.

It wasn't too crowded when we arrived, even though it was Friday slightly after 6. Maybe half the restaurant was full, and they were able to give us a table for 8 pretty easily.
author: Dianna H.

description:
Rigid Thai and i was so impressed with their interior design! It made me feel like i was sitting in Thai 60s ( i guess)  

Also i saw they offer catering in the resto, there were a party of ppl had dinner in buffet style. 

The price $$-$$$ but it worth!!
author: Tiratiwan L.

description:
Food wasnt bad but the service was horrible. Got here during lunch hour and waited for a table. There is a table outside which wasnt occupied but we were not allowed to seated as another party is already waiting. The table wasnt even cleaned for 20 minutes while we were waiting for our table.  Couldn't they speed things up and have whoever is waiting to be seated and order?

Great!  We got seated. Ordered our food and it should arrive soon as the crowd already died down. Wrong!  First order came out at a responsible amount of time. 2nd and 3rd order took additional 10 mins. 4th and 5th order took another 10 mins. The final order on our table came out after 45 mins of waiting. Other tables that ordered later than us was served before ours. We were constantly asking where is our food. The waitress just said it's coming. They didn't even have to go into the kitchen to verify and can read minds?  They are awesome!
author: Henry T.

description:
What a great place for lunch and dinner! I'm totally hooked. I came here for lunch in the middle of the week with a friend, and though it was busy, they still had a table ready for us. As we sat and looked at the menus, I marveled at the décor around the room. Neat place.

We caved into our temptation to order cocktails. Everything just sounded so delicious! I got the "Damn Good" cocktail which was just that. Spicy, strong, and damn good. For my entree, I got the roasted duck plate, served over rice with chili vinegar sauce. Would highly recommend. It satisfied a culinary craving I didn't even know I had.

Service is fast and efficient here, especially if you're going for a weekday lunch and need to get back to the office. It's not the cheapest place to eat unless you're wanting to treat yourself, but the quality of food and drinks are worth every dollar. One final upside is that they take reservations so you won't have to wait!
author: Stefanie C.

description: Big portions. I'm not the biggest fan of Thai food, but I've gone with friends and they all like it. Reservation not necessary. Service can be a little slow.
author: Neil S.

description: Saying this is the best Thai restaurant in the Bay Area is a serious understatement!! Perfectly well lit with modern cultural decor reminiscient of Thailand. The staff here is very kind and efficient and attentive. I ordered the kee mao noodles and the taste was best I've had so far. Also the quantity is more than enough. I will definitely be returning next time I'm in the mission bay SF neighborhood.
author: Rocky H.

description: We were really excited to try Saap Ver today and unfortunately our experience was very disappointing. We waited for 25 minutes for our food and at that point had to ask where our food was. She did say sorry about your food but that was it. We had the pad Thai with prawns ($4 extra for prawns and they literally give you 4 prawns). It was gloppy and didn't have great flavor. We also had the red chili beef which the server highly recommended. It was also mediocre at best. I would not go back.
author: Alison M.

description:
I had a great time with my friends eating here last week (because of my friends I was with) but there are definitely much better Thai restaurants in San Francisco than Saap Ver. We ordered almost 10 dishes since we were such a large party (10) but nothing stood out to me, which doesn't say much about their menu. They have a wide selection of food, but all the food is just meh. 

I really couldn't stand how nosy the place was. I really dislike eating at places where you have to yell across the table or even to the person next to you. 

Dishes were expensive and not large portioned.
The customer service was bad. The drinks and dishes eventually come to you, but you may have to wait awhile AND ask a few times if they remembered. I guess the only plus is that there is alot of parking in the area since it is a new developed area of SF, but if you want good thai food, go to Farmhouse Thai, Lers Ros, or Marnee Thai. Those places are worth the drive and looking for parking just because of the authentic quality of food you get.
author: Cicely T.

description:
This is a long over due review. 
Sooooo delicious, great interior and friendly service! 
Randomly stop by this place for a quick dinner
We all got surprised with overall quality and experience. 
First step in the restaurant was like, wow... Classic vintage cool interior! Is it gonna cost me $$$ to enjoy this dinner?!?
We had BBQ pork cheek, papaya salad, grilled salted whole tilapia, and Tom Yum soup. ALL dishes are so good and flavor was spot on. 
Price tag is fare at the location. 

I would come back if I'm in the neighborhood again.
author: JustinE Y.

description:
Saap Ver is my go to restaurant for authentic, inexpensive and delicious Thai cuisine. I've lost count of how many times I've eaten here since it's affordable and in the neighborhood. The place has a lively and festive feel to it, decorated with colorful banners and posters. There's a bar that offers happy hour specials too. Food gets a 4.5 from me, but my experience overall is negatively impacted by the inattentive and sluggish service (or sometimes lack of). 

Most entrees on the menu will run you about $12+ depending on what kind of protein you get, such as tofu, vegetables, chicken, pork etc. The larger and more special dishes are around $25. If you're ordering off the chef's special section make sure to ask how long it'll take. I once had to wait over an hour for the Grilled Salted Whole Tilapia Fish (more like family style entree) and really wish the waiter could have given me a heads up. I've noticed recently that the lunch offering is a smaller portion of an entree and side of rice for $12, and $15 if you add an appetizer.

Generally you can't go wrong with most options on the menu. They have it all, such as soups, rice dishes, meat dishes, noodles, etc. Portions are large. 

I remember not liking the blue river prawn chef special, it was unappetizing and pungent. I'm also not a fan of the pad thai, it's definitely not their best dish surprisingly and a bit too sweet in my opinion. I can vouch for some of my favorites though!

Service is consistently not great at this restaurant unfortunately. I recall countless times I've had to flag down waiters for pretty much everything, from ordering food to paying the bill and even getting seated. This tends to happen when the restaurant is not even that busy. At least the food comes out quickly to make up for that. It's kind of a shame though, would feel like if the service was more efficient and customer first, the business would operate faster and more effectively.

Mixed Vegetables - Delicious black bean sauce and done pretty well.

Chicken & Rice - I remember liking this one a lot. Comes with chicken broth!

Yellow Curry - Generous amount of protein, and flavorful curry made from scratch. Lately it's more watery and I recall it being thicker which I'm not a fan of. The flavor keeps me ordering it though.

Pad Cashew - Can't remember exact details, but liked this one as well.

Chicken Noodle Soup - Delicious broth and super filling!

Beef Noodle Soup - Was recommended by a waiter. Broth is very aromatic and yummy.
author: Chelsea W.

description:
Great vibe for a Friday night dinner and delicious food! 

Why I was here // I came here with a party of 4. All hungry and ready to start the night off with a good meal, we came around 7pm and it was pretty busy but we got a table.

Parking // They had some spots in front of the restaurant, but mainly it's all street parking. Gets pretty busy in the area, but parking is findable 

Atmosphere // Flashy and colorful! Rainbow flags line the ceiling and photos of old fashioned Thai movies/media culture line the walls. This place also has a disco ball. 
My only issue is that while we were there, the same song played on loop for like 30 minutes, it was "Closer" by Chainsmokers. Literally all 3 of my roommates were dying from hearing this song on replay...it was kind of funny. You should have seen us when the song changed, boy it was a party. 

Service // Honestly it's kind of hard to say if it was great service or not. They took a really long time to come and take our order. Our waiter was super nice and he was funny, but he got one of orders wrong and he didn't check up on us too often. Maybe it was because it was peak dinner hour and they were just really busy....

Food // Overall tasty, but just a few irks...
-I will note that I was really grateful that they came to refill our water/ would at least come when we called them over. 
-thai iced tea // 3.50 // Personally it was a bit too sweet, but made a nice compliment to the meal
-choo chee goong nang // 18.00 // blue river prawn, creamy coconut curry, kaffir lime leaf // This was absolutely delicious, flavoring was superb, HOWEVER, I think our shrimp was a bit too underdone for our taste....It didn't have that firm cooked shrimp texture, because I think it was still a bit raw in the center, we should have sent it back to be cooked a bit more, but we already started eating, so we continued (bad decision on our part, not the restaurant)..luckily my bf and I didn't get sick.
-Pad see ew beef // 12.00 // flat noodle, chinese broccoli, egg, soy sauce, and beef // Pretty tasty pad see ew but nothing crazy. Granted the price is decent for this dish and in line with all the other places I've been to. 
-Ginger garlic rice // 3.00 // This was REALLY good! Went well with our curry and had excellent flavoring, definitely worth the extra dollar. 

Overall, I think the flavoring is very authentic and maybe if our shrimp was cooked and they were a bit more attentive (faster service/ didn't mess up our order), this place would have been  5 stars for me.
author: Emily T.

description:
I've been here several times now and really enjoy the food. Prices are good too as they give pretty large portions. I've tried the pad lee mao, saap ver fried rice (pork belly), pad thai, green curry, and tom yum noodle soup. Everything has been delicious. The saap ver fried rice in mild is very spicy though, so be careful if you can't normally handle spicy. 

They are usually less busy before 7 pm so I haven't needed to wait for seating but it does get pretty full. They also have a promotion going on where if you post on IG/FB with their hashtag, you get a free thai iced tea.

Overall 5 stars as it's definitely my favorite Thai place in Soma and now a go-to spot for dinner.
author: Sophia H.

description: I came here with a group of friends  around 11 today and the food was very good Maybe they change head chef? We ordered pad kee mao, pad Thai and glass noodle. Definitely coming back here again. Thank you for such a delicious meal.
author: Aniko N.

description:
When I walked in, I was super impressed. It's really well decorated with old Thai newspaper clippings, ads, etc and gives it a really unique vibe compared to your normal Thai restaurant. The decor is really cute, there's a giant TV, and a large bar. During Warriors season, this is def going to be a little secret spot to watch the game without a lot of crowd. 

However, I was disappointed with the vegetarian options and the food itself. 

There's plenty of options and not just your usual pad thai and red curry, there's a ton of stuff I haven't heard of before. However, there weren't a TON of vegetarian options, and I'm pretty sure that even those probably had fish sauce in them and stuff :/ 

I ordered the cashew tofu and it was really, really bland. I had to douse it with some sauces... quite disappointing since it almost tasted like some random cheap takeout. it also took a while for the food to come out. 

The prices were reasonable..$12 an entree.
author: Aria S.

description:
This place is my new favorite Thai restaurant. The decor is fun and vibrant, the staff are always nice and welcoming, and they have a full bar. And that's not even the best part. The food is top notch. I have to say, I LOVE Thai food so I eat it a lot, so trust me, you must eat here. 

In addition to the standards (Pad Thai, a selection of curries, etc), they have some interesting and unusual dishes. I'm making it my mission to try everything on their menu because I like it so much. Some standouts are the stir fried cabbage (so simple, yet SO delicious) and the rice salad with sausage. The rice salad is a nice variant on the spicy/limey/sweet/salty salad, but with a nice textural addition of the crispy rice. My mouth is watering just thinking about it. 

Come. Eat. Enjoy!
author: Phillip H.

description:
Thai sausage crispy rice salad. It's my new mantra. Say it with me. Then get it and experience scrumptious tart umami crunchy bliss.

So frickin' delicious. Love the authentic style - this isn't your average takeout Thai.  The flavors are much more pronounced, and the variety on the menu surpasses the boring satay and curry offerings. That said, the red curry? Pretty damn good. Yay for unique Thai offerings!
author: Archana P.

description:
Saap Ver SF just sold their liquor license. No more wonderful exotic cocktails.  They also paired down what used to be a nice, creative wine selection to a few cheap choices that you'd expect at Applebees. 

Food is still good, but it's such a sad shadow of what it used to be. Going to be looking for another Thai go-to restaurant. Done with Saap.
author: Nancy W.

description: Good basic Thai. This is our go to spot for Thai food - which is probably because we live across the street but still yummy none the less. Fruity drinks are always great and I tend to go for the pad see ew or crispy chicken fried rice. Beware those who do not like spicy foods - they aren't kidding when they say spicy. And if you're someone who loves the spicy stuff, be careful as well! They'll go all out trying to make it fiery hot if you ask for it.
author: Leina K.

description:
Thai food is hot. I got a fried pork salad and it scorched my mouth. They gave me a complimentary Thai tea because I was crying. Curry was good. 

The fried sardine plate was not good. Unless you like fried sardines. Then maybe. It comes with fried eggplant and steamed broccoli. I was confused.
author: Ryan C.

description:
Saap is awesome! Be adventurous and try out everything on the menu!

Chef Kobe is amazing at what he does and he brings the taste from Thailand to San Francisco.
Steven really knows how to run a restaurant and makes sure you are taken care of; amazing service. 

Saap is great for after-work drinks as well. Sun-dried beef jerky makes for a great snack at the bar while sipping on Singha beer.

With so many choices - it's hard to pick one, but if I were to give one of their dishes a try, it would be their fried rice with crispy pork belly. Their fried rice is packed with flavor and the pork belly is super crispy. (Pair this with a Thai ice tea and you're GOLDEN!)
author: Sam K.

description:
I must be honest and say that the lower Yelp reviews for Saap Ver has made me hesitant to try this spot for the past year...until a friends persistent reco a few weeks ago. And boy was I wrong to stay away from Saap Ver til now! 

Those same friends and I went to Thailand last year, and we've been craving legit Thai street food ever since. And I'm not talking about the watered down curries and pad thais that every other Thai restaurant serves in this city. I'm talking about the spices, the layers of flavor, the genuine uniqueness of this cuisine. And Saap Ver has that down to a tee. 

Decor - reminder of all the fun, street style of Thailand (without the dirty street feels)

Wait staff - first visit really disappointed me. My friend had to apologize to me several times saying she'd never seen the restaurant that busy before. Our waitress didn't bring us our menus for a while. Or water. And forgot the main dish we order...the salted fish, which takes a bit longer to make. To be fair, they were catering a 20+ bday party, plus everyone else that night. It did seem busier than usual. 
Which is why I decided to give them a second chance. The second visit was the best! The waitress was attentive, informative, and extremely friendly. The restaurant was also a lot less busy that night. 

Food - the star of the show! Dishes I tried were the whole grilled salted fish (twice), Tom yum seafood fried rice, papaya salad (mild), and the Po tak soup. Get the salted fish!! Don't walk. RUN! It's that good. I'd go there just to eat that if I had $29 to drop on a whole fish every meal. Seriously though, get the fish. No regrets. 

Since the reco a few weeks ago, I've been here two times. The first visit was unfortunately an overall 3 star experience, but I was willing to give it another try. The second visit was fortunately an overall 5 star experience! Here's 4 stars to hoping that they can staff up or learn to roll with the punches better!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Came here with a friend and got seated down immediately.

We ordered three dishes and shared them all. Do this because, honestly, trying more of their food is a good idea. Favorite was definitely the green curry we ordered. They also give rice with it, which is nice, since I have been to Thai places that make you order the rice with it.

Anyway, it is a great place to come for Thai food. There isn't really parking near the area.
author: Paulina L.

description:
The place is loud, the service was slow, but the food is pretty good and largely portioned. There is plenty of seating, edgy and loud decor, and several large monitors for playing march madness recaps.

My friend got a medium spicy shrimp dish and ended up feeling dizzy, lightheaded, and allergic from the spiciness. That's when you know it's good stuff. So if you like spicy, this is the place to test your levels.

Our chicken wing appetizer had hella garlic flakes and was pretty good too but I'm not a huge fan of that burnt aftertaste so might not get that again.

The pad see ew I got was pretty good, not as much chicken or egg as I would have liked, but great flavor that wasn't too salty or sweet I was able to bring a bowl back as leftovers. Wish they had more veggies in it that weren't bitter-tasting from being overcooked. :/
author: Lydia Z.

description: Awesome place. First of all I'm Thai. I love this place and this is the first time that I visit SF. The food is 100% authentic Thai food. If you expect to try real Thai food! JUST COME. Look at my photo and order from them. Highly recommend !!
author: Meenarin P.

description: Nice Pad Kee Mow Chicken. Well spiced, service was good. Ambience is pretty cool too. Decent overall.
author: Dhruvil B.

description: I'm so glad my brother recommended this place!  I have eaten a lot of Thai food in my life and the food here is amazingly delicious.  This place is best enjoyed with a large crowd, so come with a group!
author: Marnie S.

description: Placed an order on Uber Eats, they accepted it. After an hour of the ETA getting more and more pushed out, I called them several times. They answered on the third try and told me they just saw the order and it would be another 30 mins before the order arrived. I couldn't wait bc I had to leave for the airport. Extremely disappointing experience and they seemed to be laughing about it on the phone.
author: Ted M.

description:
Been back two more times. 
Had the rad na the second time and it was okay, not bad.

Today we went for lunch, and THOUGHT we got lucky by ordering before a larger party but food still took awhile to get. 
I'm always a sucker for noodles, so I ordered the wonton noodle soup, I KNOW I KNOW. wonton noodle soup at a thai place? 
Don't do it, the soup was super bland and peppery.
Hot sauce couldn't fix it, I needed fish sauce or some hoisin sauce. 

I shall pass on this place.
author: Christine M.

description: Amazing food, kitchen & service run like a well oiled machines. Minus one star because slightly overpriced IMHO.
author: Claire R.

description: Overly sweet and way too spicy.    My friend had the pork with salad, but the salad was just iceberg lettuce.    My Chicken with basil was way too sweet and overly spiced.   Won't be back
author: Mark K.

description:
TLDR - Solid Thai restaurant, very reasonable prices, some regional dishes, lively vibe

Not your typical Thai restaurant. Saap Ver has more of a lively bar vibe that was reminiscent of the nightlife in Thailand. Retro decor. Casual, energetic ambiance.

The menu is very extensive here, like most Thai restaurants, and can be a little overwhelming. Unlike other Thai places I've been to, they have some more regional dishes that I don't normally see on menus like khao kha moo (five spices pork leg). The prices are very reasonable here, especially given it's SF, and they don't skimp on portion sizes to compensate. 

We ordered 4 dishes between the 3 of us and it was more than plenty. I found the more "American" dishes like pad thai and curry to be disappointing while the less commonly ordered som tom and BBQ chicken tasted more authentic in flavor. I'd come back to try more of their regional dishes!

* SOM TOM GRILLED PRAWNS ($13) - 4.5/5
[green papaya salad, chili, cherry tomato, green bean, ground peanut, grilled prawn, fish sauce]
Very well balanced papaya salad! Spicy, acidic, salty and sweet - just like in Thailand. My only disappointment was that there was literally just one grilled prawn, sliced into two halves.

* BBQ CHICKEN ($12) - 4/5
[thai style bbq chicken with sweet chili sauce]
Solid. Came with 4 large pieces of chicken - 2 drumsticks and 1 thigh cut into 2 pieces - served with a sweet chili dipping sauce as well as a salty/fish chili dipping sauce. The meat wasn't the best I've had in texture and was a little dry at spots, but the skin was crispy and it was a generous portion for the price.

* PAD THAI HOR KAI ($16) - 3/5
[egg wrap pad thai - pan-fried rice noodle, prawn, peanut, bean sprouts]
Disappointing. I had this in Bangkok and haven't seen it anywhere in SF except Saap Ver, so I was eager to try it. I honestly wasn't expecting it to be anything like the one I had in Bangkok, but their pad thai really fell short. The noodles were too chewy and stuck together in clumps, and the flavor was too sweet.

* YELLOW CURRY WITH BEEF ($12) - 3/5
[curry powder, turmeric, coconut milk, potato, carrot, yellow onion]
Standard curry flavor. We got ours medium spicy but it tasted very mild to me. The potato, carrots and onion were tender soft, but the texture of the beef was tough and chewy. Felt like cheap cuts, but at least they were pretty generous with the amount of it. Maybe go with a different protein, but nothing special about the curry itself.
author: Jessie L.

description:
Oh my gosh! This place is amazing! ....the minute we walk in, the decor, the menu, the foods, the friendly staff, the music, the list goes on!  

I'd have I say....it's very authentic here....some of the dishes taste even better than when I had them in Thailand....namely "the papaya salad - with blue crabs and pla-rah" ("pla-rah" is a fermented fish that's very prominent in eastern Thai cuisine).  It takes an acquired taste ...super-delicious if you've been to Thailand and have had papaya salad there, you'd know what I'm talking about. and this place has it done just right! The secret is in the sauce, says the owner! We had to come back for dinner again within days, because we were so impressed!

They have specialty dishes like the whole fish grilled with crusted salt....whaaaat?!?! Delicious and tender and comes with 3 types of sauces for dipping. (Be sure you can handle a whole fish if you order this dish, it's humongous!) 

You should try their grilled bananas for desert...it's almost like salty caramel bananas, sliced thin and grilled....but with coconut flavor in it.  The owner said they used three different types of sugar to sweeten it...don't worry, they're all natural sugars! (No sweeteners)

Make sure to ask for the specials of the day, we had curry crab last time and we had to take even the left over sauce home...haha...

Go have yourself a good authentic Thai foods and brings family or friends!  so you can have more variety and share some of the most delicious Thai foods you'll have in a long time, guaranteed!
author: Issy M.

description: Yum yum yum. Authentic Thai food. It's a bit more than your regular Thai fare, but worth it. Good service too. A go - to for my BF and me.
author: Angela H.

description: I have a few complaints about Saap Ver. The service is pretty bad overall, if you run out of water don't plan on getting a refill any time soon. 3 of the 4 times I've came for lunch, the waiter/ waitress has gotten the orders wrong which led to long wait times to get the correct meal. The pricing is over the top compared to other Thai restaurants in the area. $14+ for any dish that is not an appetizer. Also the menu doesn't make sense in terms of the pricing for certain items like tofu pad Thai. They only list the pad Thai with prawns which is $16. The portions have also been pretty inconsistent; it's either pretty small or somewhat acceptable. The owners of this place need to reevaluate their business.
author: Brandon M.

description:
I love love love this place!

this place is not typical Thai restaurants that you commonly see everywhere.                          

this is Isaan Thai (Northeastern Region of Thailand) that is similar to Laotian Cuisine.
bold, spicy, pungent, shrimp paste, grilled meats, raw vegetables, and sticky rice.
better than the southern style Thai food that you're familiar with.
this place is definitely one of the best restaurants I've ever been to in San Francisco.
great food, lively place.
author: Rudy H.

description:
I used to have only 1 favorite thai restaurant in the city and that was Ler Ros. Now I can say I have 2. My benchmark for "authentic" Thai is measured by the papaya salad. I never loved Papaya salad until I visited Thailand and now I am obsessed.

A good papaya salad to me has to have the perfect combo of crunchy green papaya, tangy lime, salty fish sauce, spicy thai chilli peppers, and sweetness from the sugar. 

I've tried the crab papaya salad at both Ler Ros and Saap Ver...and both were utterly delicious. A must-try.

Another dish that I really haven't been able to find done well anywhere (except for my home town in Boston) is the Tom Yum noodle soup. This is made with ground pork, ground peanuts, in a spicy/sour broth with rice noodles. I will be coming back for this! 

My friend's go-to dish is the 5-spice pig leg (cut up into pieces not whole) on rice. It comes with this spicy side sauce that you should taste before you drench your plate with it. It's FIRE. This was also a very tasty dish.

There are so many more dishes I want to try. Took a peek at dishes on other tables and everything looked really good.  The dipping platters especially look interesting.

The decor is so fun. It's decorated like a Thai movie theater with faces of Thai stars as the wall paper.
author: Emily Y.

description: Cool atmosphere and tasty food. Not enough bar staff though...silly mistake that management can easily fix
author: Jess G.

description:
I went here for the first time with a friend today after hearing pretty rave reviews about the food. That said, we received fair warning about the less than stellar service. On a Saturday evening around 6:30, the restaurant was fairly busy. It was definitely a party atmosphere with karaoke and singer songwriter group, not to mention the Hornitas girls walking around offering free shots. We were sat right away, but a server did not come to our table until ten to fifteen minutes after we had already decided on our order.

My friend and I ordered the som tum with grilled prawns and the steamed chicken with ginger rice. The chicken dish came out first. The chicken was plated messily and there was a piece that was too rare for our comfort. The sauce that this dish comes with is spicy and delicious, however. My previous experience with kao mun gai (sp?) is with a delicously oily and shiny rice. This rice was not like that, but served its purpose. My friend and I were starved, so we polished this off.

Then, we waited. And waited for the som tum. We were reassured it was coming, but we had to ask a couple times for the dish's status update. When it finally came, I was disappointed to see that there were only two prawns on the plate and even more so when I bit into the one I dished up. It was pretty soft and I actually questioned if it was cooked all the way through. Asides from this though, the flavors were good and the medium spiciness we asked for was quite spicy.

Asides from the initial lapse in attention from our server, the service from pretty much everyone else in the restaurant was pretty good. But all in all, Saap Ver is pretty close to greatness, but not quite there with seamless service, entree timing, and cook temps. Solid option for Thai if you are in the area though if you care to take the risk!
author: Jung-In S.

description: A solid option for Thai in the mission bay/Potrero hill area. This place is pretty big inside, wide open space so it can get a little loud at times. As far as the food it's good, I enjoyed it. Got the pad see eww and it was definitely one of the better ones I've had in the city. The appetizers were ok, pretty stand for most Thai joints. While I was here they had durian wth sticky rice on the menu for dessert, I've never tried durian and decided to try it. Well I now understand why people like it or hate it, I'm of the camp that it's not for me. While i didn't like it, I liked that they had it on their menu to try because very few places would serve it. Service here was fast and friendly and I would definitely go back if I'm in the mood for Thai
author: Peter P.

description: Meh. Food wasn't great. Service sucked. My husband and I got the Crab Fried Rice and Green Curry. Crab Fried Rice was not flavorful and oily. Green Curry was unflavorful and was probably one of the worse curries I've had. How is this place a 4 out of 5 stars?
author: C O.

description: This is my favorite Thai spot in sf. The staff is Thai--even the bar instructions are all in Thai. They use quality ingredients in both their food and drinks. Cocktails are bomb. Not too sweet, balanced flavors.
author: Christine K.

description:
Spicy tom yum soup!! Don't understand how this place only has 3.5 stars. One of their other noodle soups is really good too!

And their saap ver drink is delicious, more spicy than the spicy tom yum soup haha.
author: Cal C.

description: Most of the food was good, except for the pad thai wrapped in an egg omelet, the noodles were bitey, like it wasn't cooked long enough and was hard. Not good since the dish was $18, expensive for pad thai in my opinion. Service was good, I did enjoy the Issan sausage. Probably won't be back.
author: Angela D.

description:
I only go to two Thai places in the city recommended from my Thai friends and this is one of them. 

We ordered the Sea Bass Clay Pot Dinner for $25. It was delicious. Fish was cooked perfectly. Also ordered the Cripsy Pork Belly Green Bean Dinner for $16. Pork belly had a nice crisp to the edges but super tender elsewhere. Also had good heat to it so was loving that.

Excited to keep coming back and trying everything on the menu. Haven't gone wrong yet!
author: Mandi W.

description:
Been here twice for bday parties & really loved the food! You know it's a good sign when you walk in & see a big contingent from the local Thai temple eating here.

Shrimp rolls, pork belly, larb ( spicy!!!), som tum, crab fried rice, curries all faves.
Tasty tofu & veg options for our vegetarian friends too.
Coconut ice cream was rich & decadent. 
Full bar w friendly bartender, the owner came & had shots a us. They get very busy on weekend nights but it's worth any wait ( and parking in this area is actually decent!)
author: H H.

description:
I rarely feel compelled to review a place so soon after eating, but this place made me want to for the wrong reasons

My main complaints, in summary, are poor value/portion size and problems with the food quality.

I usually walk by this place and it tends to be busy and lively every evening, so I thought I'd check it out. I ordered two things here, some grilled pork shoulder and crab fried rice. The crab fried rice had disappointingly little crab and little crab flavor to it (compared to say Farmhouse Thai). The grilled pork shoulder tasted good, but very little was provided. The pork came with a tasty sauce, however, as I poured it out I noticed a strange lump. When prodding this lump, it popped and revealed itself to be a mass of undissolved/unmixed rice powder (see photos). Pretty unappetizing, and suggestive of corner cutting/not much care being put in.
author: Neal B.

description:
The best and most authentic Thai food you can get in the city. The decor and ambiance is awesome but the food is even better! There are items here that cannot be found at other thai restaurants.  

Some of my favorites were the Raw crab salad- YES it's RAW and it's delicious and sweet. They load it up with garlic and thai chilis.  

We also had the Larb Fish which was also very delicious. This is a fried whole but what's nice about this dish is that they dice up the fish meat for you!

We also had the curry crab which was very flavorful. other dishes we had were the bloody clams, papaya salad, tom yum soup, and scallops. I will definitely be back!
author: Emi K.

description: Great Thai place with just an unique modern fushion atmosphere. Menus selection is quite nice! I often get togo orders here and they're always super fast. Although the quality isn't always consistent. My first time getting their Pad See Ew was amazing but the most recent time tasted like the chef forgot to add salt. So just keep in mind that this place might be a hit or miss.
author: Mandy H.

description:
The restaurant is very nice but no air-conditioner in day time (I have been there around 2pm).
There are some fly around my thai food all the time.
That make me annoyed.
Chicken overrice is not recommended because chicken is tasteless and very hard. But I would recommended some spicy thai food such as crab salad, cooked cockle
author: Katthy W.

description: Had high expectations because I heard this was authentic. The food was luke warm and tasted a bit off - hey maybe I'm just not used to "authentic Thai food". Overpriced and underwhelmed.
author: Adriana R.

description:
Most of the food is good, but never get the meatballs, which are like tire rubber.

I'm a frequent customer -- at least 3x per month. They get my order wrong about 50% of the time. Usually it's a recipe change (I'm allergic to mushrooms, STOP adding mushrooms to recipes) or inconsistent spiciness level ("medium" varies between 100 and 10,000 Scoville units). Sometimes they forget an item, and frequently they don't notice my Eat24 order until I arrive 15-25 min later to pick up the food. I wouldn't order ahead if I knew I'd still have to sit there in the restaurant. I'll order somewhere else next time.
author: Andrew F.

description: I was hoping to like this place a lot. The service has been nice. The has been hit or miss. Had a squid dish with great flavor but was over cooked some. I did generally like it. I ordered the whole fish Larb and got just whole fish. It was good and the sauce were great. Just the wrong item. The Larb wonton didn't have a whole lot of Larb Flavor. The Chili beef was different with a sour heat. I liked that quite a bit
author: Dennis M.

description:
What a surprise this place was! The menu features more authentic dishes than others with a festive street food and cinema vibe. As my husband said, "Saap Ver is unapologetically Thai and I love it" which means their spiciness and flavor intensity does not compromise for the masses but their name lives up to it - damn delicious. Their service can be slow because they lack bussers and runners...but they comped some thai iced teas for us which made up for it.  Everyone smiles and are very friendly. 

This is what we recommend so far: Thai sausage crispy rice salad, Spicy TomYum noodle soup (I can literally get a bowl just for myself - it's that good), whole fish dish (any), Thai style BBQ chicken, durian sticky rice.

Dishes you can skip: Crying Tyger (nothing special, really) and the pad thai. 

Quick tip: Make a reservation during peak eating times. Otherwise you can easily snag a table later or much earlier. Street parking is somewhat plenty.
author: Johanna P.

description: Really disappointing. I'm no cheapo, but it was really overpriced for the portions we received and the quality of the food. And I guess I'm getting old because the music was stupid loud for my taste, and the tables were too close to each other.
author: Angela R.

description:
I like to order my Thai "Thai hot," or Level 5. It almost always disappoints, with a few memorable exceptions: Sabuy Sabuy II on San Pablo in Berkeley and Ruen Thai in Roseville. My idea of hot is nose running, throat closing, night sweats--you get the picture, a general week-long burn. At Sabuy Sabuy II (which used to be called something else, was it Plearn?), I insisted on Thai hot and the server rolled her eyes all the way back to Thailand. I'm all, bring it. The burn was incredibly fierce--like stop on the way home to get milk to drink immediately-fierce, almost inedible. You know how I likes it. Ruen Thai is less inedibly hot, but still well seasoned. 

SV is my neighborhood Thai spot, I practically live on top of the place. It's the sort of unsuspecting strip mall restaurant that you relish finding - the proverbial hole in the wall--the third Thai restaurant I've found that knows how to do stupid hot. A diamond in the rough. 

I think SV is the best Thai food in San Francisco, bar none. Of course, like everything, that's relative. I hate to complain, but this city's Thai offerings underwhelm. The east bay's Thai selection is sooo much better. And Sacramento kicks the east bay's ass. I've actually been to an incredible place in Modesto? I digress.

One night I ordered Pad Thai on the Yelp app for pickup, Thai hot, no bean sprouts, add tofu, add beef: a joyful carbo-load. Yes, I know that Pad Thai is the spaghetti of Thai food, but hear me out. This dish is a good barometer for measuring the tastiness of  your Thai. It's like vanilla ice cream, I'm most impressed when that is done well, and it's almost never done well anywhere. The Pad Thai at SV was the best I've had anywhere, ever, period. And it was soooo hot without compromising the other flavors of the dish. 

I've had a good portion of the menu by now, naturally. My favorites include the red curry, Pad-khee-mao, Pad-see-ew, Pad-see-you? I've not had anything bad here, everything is delicious and authentic. The one time I've dined in with my sister, no one spoke English. The bar is very interesting. I like to people watch there. The service is great and super fast. 

Very special. Happy face.
author: Sunny S.

description:
Such a hipster nice, cozy and comfortable place. The food and its presentation are superb. Authentic local
distinctive Thai food, all should try!
author: Max B. K.

description: I probably come here once a week because its that good (I also live very close which helps). Anyways, this place is awesome! The atmosphere is fun but relaxed; great place for a group or to sit at the bar and watch a game. Before coming I was not the biggest on Thai food but this place changed the game for me as you can select the spiciness of your dishes (they always ask mild, medium or hot). I started at mild and am now working my way up to hot! I've tried a lot now and it's  all good but my staples are: 1) Crispy prawn rolls, 2) samosas (very different but bomb), 3) Ka pow chicken (medium), 4) crab fried rice (omg so good)! The Thai milk tea is really good too. Their new cocktail menu is small but good. They have a couple of drinks that are served inside fruit and you can watch the bartender carve out the center of the pineapple when you order. All in all, highly recommend!
author: Kendra W.

description:
If you are looking for an authentic Thai food, then this is the right place for you. They have a full bar serving you lots of great in-house cocktail. This is a place for everyone. It has a nice decoration. 

I came here on Sunday night. There were 15 tables at that time. Tge food came out fast. I went with one of my friends. We decided to eat Northern food and Northeastern food for this meal. We had Salt-crusted Grilled Fish, Somtum Pu Plara (Papaya Salad with Salted Crab), Spicy Blue Crab Salad, and Grilled Pork with Thai Spicy Sauce. For dessert, we had roasted banana. For drinks, we had 3 cocktails and a Thai beer. 

Salt-crusted Grilled Fish 4.5/5
-It serves with 3 small sides; Northern Thai Green Chili Dip, Thai Spicy Sauce, and Thai Sweet Sauce. Northern Thai Green Chilli Dip is probably the best when eating with this meal. 

Somtum Pu Plara (Papaya Salad with Salted Crab) 3.5/5
-The taste is great but the the sauce is too little, so the taste didn't really compliment the raw papaya. Papaya is a bit too hard for my taste. 

Spicy Blue Crab Salad 5/5
-This is my favorite! If you like Thai Salad, then go for it. 

Grilled Pork with Thai Spicy Sauce 4.5/5
-The grilled pork was so juicy. It could have been better with the better sauce. 

Roasted Banana 5/5
-I never have this kind of taste in Thailand before. It was unexpected delicious. It is far better than anywhere. 

Leo Beer 5/5
-Surprisingly, they serve it! It is a to-go beer for any Thai people. 

Tippsy emcee 5/5
It is spicy! and it is damn goood. 

Saap ver dam good 5/5
The best of the best! One of my favorite cocktails of all time. I had two of them. The smell of them were incredibly good as well as the taste. You have to try them! 

Service 5/5
The service is great. I didn't have to wait for long. Servers are nice and friendly. They took care customers really well. 

Space 5/5
Love the decor. They have lots of small square tables, long table,  and long bar. It should be a good space to throw a party! 

Overall, this is a Thai restaurant that you must pay a visit once you are in San Francisco.
author: Paris S.

description:
I MUCH prefer Lers and Farmhouse for comparable Thai; food came out slow but maybe because it was the grand opening?

* Pad thai in crepe - decently flavored, saucy pad thai. Have had better.
* Fried rice with pork belly - Very tasty, very spicy. Loved the super crunchy pork
* Pork plate - Strips of pork were very dry, veggies were from frozen; but I liked the pasty sauce -- too expensive for what it was.
* Duck salad - Very small, good but standard
* Papaya salad with crab - Very fishy... crab shells, but no actual crab. Confused.

Recommend ordering their famous for fried fish which takes 40 min
author: Jess C.

description:
I am a big fan. This place is awesome.  First just the ambiance and the whole place is screams cool stylish Thai people. It has this retro, thai western movie vibe to it. It has the menu on the movie theatre style sign and the wall paper is all thai movie posters. Even the chairs are vibrant and different. The place has a full bar, and one time I went they had live thai music. (Thai musician singing in thai but western style).  Service is also so friendly and excellent. They take really good care of you. There's a ton of wait staff. 

The menu is full of delicious things: chef's picks, apps, curries, salads, noodles, noodle soups, etc etc. There is also more northern style dishes which is different from a lot of places. They also have happy hour 5pm -7pm and some apps are $6, and drink specials. 
Everything we've ordered has been excellent, flavorful, and medium spicy is pretty spicy. I find myself sweating while I"m eating but loving it because it's so flavorful and delicious. 

The one complaint is that we ordered chicken wings.. and you know how chicken wings usually have those like two bones? Well the chicken wings came and it seemed like they broke the regular chicken wings into two pieces and called each separate bone as a "wing".... check out the pics. It was sad... Still delicious but sad. 

Cool part is that it's in a part of town where there isn't a lot else going on during dinner, so parking is really easy. Win!
author: Veronica L.

description:
I've been here three times. The first two times everything was fantastic. The third time it felt like a completely different restaurant. The pad kee mao had almost no noodles and was mostly under-seasoned stir-fried vegetables. The pumpkin curry was similar--mostly soggy vegetables with a small portion of very watery curry sauce. There was also a large chunk of shrimp paste that hadn't been mixed into the sauce. Nothing like our first two visits. Very disappointing. Still giving it three stars because the service was good I'm hopeful that the food was a fluke.

EDIT: just learned that they have a new chef, so I suppose it's not a fluke.
author: Andrew T.

description: Sometimes the waits are long, but it's worth it. Some of the best Thai food I've ever had. Lately I've been enjoying the ka-pow chicken with brown rice.
author: Ron B.

description: Pretty good, nice place, good energy. Food came quickly and was what I expected. Got pad Thai, sausage, and Tom yum. All decent
author: JJ W.

description:
My friend from Thailand recommended this place, and this place is authentic. 

Some people said things about the servers not being attentive, I think they're fine, you just need to be a little more proactive. They are nice though. The place is nice to eat for dinner as well, and good to share.

I would definitely come back because this place has authentic food that sometimes you don't find in other thai restaurants in the city.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Saap ver deserves 5 stars had the food not been so salty. Overall, I enjoyed the feel of the place, amount of food, quality of food, cleanliness, attentive staff (but maybe it was because most of the tables were empty at 8 PM on a Wednesday night). 

price was very reasonable. Three of us spent $17 each on three dishes to share and we finished everything! It was perfect amount of food. 

1) papaya salad with crab (way too salty, otherwise tasty!). The spiceyness opened our pallet. I suggest for you to ask the waiters to make the salad less salty. 
2) pumpkin curry with chicken. Wow, delicious! Pumpkin was cooked perfectly as it wasn't too soft (smushy). We also ordered one jasmine and one sticky rice. One came in a traditional bowl and another in bamboo basket. 
3) BBQ pork noodles with wonton. This dish tastes more like a noodle dish from HK. The soup was flavorful without being heavy.
author: Dana Z.

description: Good food, good beer. I asked for medium spicy and it put a hurt on me. Got to work my way up for spicy.
author: Gordon L.

description:
The most authentic Thai restaurant in SF. 

If you're after good quality Thai food that actually tastes the way it should, then look no further. 

The Kana Moo Krob here is one of the best I've had, it's definitely the best I've had in the USA. So far every dish I've had here was spot on in terms of flavor and ingredients. 

Most Thai places in the USA have adapted to the local palate and the dishes have been so dumbed down it's basically the same sauce for each dish. Not here. The best way to judge a Thai place is on the Pad Thai and this restaurant nails it along with all other dishes 

One of my favorite restaurants in the area.
author: Matthew B.

description: Love it. Especially the small bites. Fish cake, or the traditional sausage. And their saap ver cocktail that taste like tom yum in a very good way.
author: Dr. Cordula K.

description:
Excellent Thai food in the Design District area (across the street from Dumpling Time). It's very underrated because it's never very crowded, but it's one of the best Thai food I've ever had. It's good for me I guess because I never have to wait to be seated.

I might even put their food on par with Kin Khao.

The staff is also super friendly, and they have good cocktails and drinks. 

When you go for lunch, also ask for the dinner menu. There's a lot more specialty items on the dinner menu, and they'll serve it during lunch.
author: Richard S.

description:
Awesome Thai food!

I always get the spicy noodles. It's full of crazy amounts of ingredients in a bowl of noodles and soup. The soup tastes a little sweet and sour--just thinking about it makes me want to order one now. The spiciness is legit--they usually give the spice sauce to you as a side dish, so you can make it as spicy as you want.

The wait staff are all very courteous and nice. The ambience inside is great, with giant paintings on the wall of vintage thai movie posters that look like they are from a past generation. Pretty cool spot to hang out for beer, lunch, and dinner.

Definitely a place I want to go back to again and again.
author: Henry L.

description: Very cool informal place to eat Thai food with a relaxed atmosphere. Yummy!
author: Maria M.

description:
HORRIBLE SERVICE AND BLAND FOOD

I made an online order this afternnon and it wasn't ready when I arrived 30 min later. Not the end of the world - but then I waited another 30 min while they put my order behind a handful of other orders. They didn't offer any apologies or credits toward future meals. Nothing. I asked to speak to a manager and was told the manager left for the day.

I brought the food to my office and it's very BLAND. I'll never eat here again. With so many options for Thai food, why waste time or money on horrible service and boring food?
author: Alex W.

description: My family and I were in SF for one night, and of course we love Thai/Laos food. We made a reservation for Lao Table the night before, but when we got there, there was NO parking so we didn't get to eat there. The next day we planned going back to Lao Table, but it wasn't open till 5pm. So we decided to try this place, and wow! I'm just in love with their food! Absolutely delicious! Everything was so authentic! If you're looking for real Thai food, this is the place to go! Will definitely be going back while I'm in SF.
author: Lynn M.

description:
Impressing the hard to impress is tough.

Birthday boy wanted to go to Saison for his Dirty 30 Birthday. I laughed over text and said, I'll do even better...

*SURPRISE*

Saap Ver, the newest Thai restaurant in SF...with 8 of your closest friends! 

Shockingly, he was happy I choose Saap Ver as it came recommended by his trainer. 

Opening up last month in the old Grand Pu Bah space, Saap Ver serves authentic Thai food in a very dark, kitschy space. Street parking was plentiful. 

I appreciate having lots of choices but the 100+ item menu was daunting because most items can't be found in your cookie cutter Thai restaurant like King of Thai or Osha. The menu lacks organization; i.e. soup was listed in 3 different sections. There's also two other boards of "chef specials" with another 20+ items which made things even more overwhelming. A lot of ingredients present in the dishes aren't listed on the menu so if you have food allergies, let your server know. There's a full bar.

We ordered 15 dishes, some with double orders to share in a group. There were more misses than hits.

: : S  O  L  I  D : : 
*Nam Kao Tod: Crispy Rice Salad ($12): http://bit.ly/1pFesz3
